comment.author: 29056926@N02
comment._content: A look at the midway (a mix of exotic cultures on display), with buildings around the north end of the lagoon, and finally Lake Michigan in the distance. In the foreground on the left is the German Village. Beyond it is the Javanese village, brought bit by bit from Java. In the immediate foreground on the right is the Turkish Village and then the circular building is the "Panorama" indoor exhibit of the Burmese Alps (Switzerland). The Dutch settlement is just beyond the Alps. Then a viaduct bisects the photo from left to right. Beyond that on the left is the Japanese Bazaar, Irish Village, a glass company and an "electric scenic theater". On the right is an animal show (which has text on the top only visible from the Ferris Wheel and the balloon while it was still flying), another glass company (Venice & Murano), and a log cabin built in 1776 (not visible in the photo). Then the dark, overpassing railroad tracks again cut across the photo before the exposition entrances, which you can see in the larger version of the photo. The domes are the Illinois Buliding on the left and the US Government Building on the right. Great navigable (though kind of like looking through a peephole because it's small) map here. You'll find the Ferris Wheel way up on the left near the end of the midway, which runs between 59th and 60th. By the way, the "L" tracks visible on the right along 60th were built just for the fair. They no longer exist. The midway is now a park running along the University of Chicago. Comparing the map linked above and Live Maps, it appears that the university and Chicago Parks have placed two basketball courts where the Ferris Wheel used to be.

comment.author: 73286033@N00
comment._content: Nope, not only basketball courts, it is really a permanent Ice Rink!  When they were digging the foundation for the rink they found the foundation for the original Ferris Wheel under what had been a soccer pitch for decades!

comment.author: 83979593@N00
comment._content:
More from our researcher Ed per the Annotated bibliography World's Columbian Exposition, Chicago, 1893 : supplement / by G.L. Dybwad, Joy V. Bliss:

This book contains a map of the site including the Midway which verifies the placement of Ferris’ Wheel, from which the photograph was taken.  

The German Village is as noted in the left foreground.  The map indicates the Dutch Settlement in the location noted by Roketpad.  This may be the Javanese Village, as all of Indonesia (including Java) was a Dutch colony.  

The locations noted by Roketpad on the right are the Turkish Village with the Panorama of the “Burmese” (should be Bernese) Alps, beyond which is the Natatorium and Café, and then the Dutch Settlement.  

Beyond the Japanese Bazaar on the left the map indicates the Liberty Glass Company.  The Irish Village in our source map is located in the farthest right corner at Stony island Avenue which is at the east perimeter of the Midway.  

The Hagenbeck’s Animal Show is noted correctly as is the Murano glass expo from Venice which sits next to the Illinois Central Station.   
The domes of the Illinois and U.S. Government Buildings seem correctly noted.  Our source locates Ferris’ Wheel approximately midway along the Midway Plaisance.

comment._content: This photo is amazing. I am Turkish, and I recognize the fountain, the obelisk, and the Ottoman style mosque, which are all replicas of the real things. For an old engraving: flickr.com/photos/profdrzihnisinir/449155729/ and more information: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hippodrome_of_Constantinople Does any knows a web link that shows present day view of the exposition site?

comment.author: 29056926@N02
comment._content:
@ProfDrZihniSinir:  It's all gone!

Here's a great aerial view on Flickr, recommend clicking through to the largest view:

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/mindfrieze/2195935353/]

This is looking from Lake Michigan.  In the foreground is Jackson Park, which was the main body of the Fair (the Lagoon, the Court of Honor, etc).  The park/boulevard bracketed by four streets, heading up in the middle of the frame, is the Midway Plaissance.  It runs to Washington Park.  The Midway was the site of the international and "fun" exhibits.  You can see a white rectangle about 2/3 of the way up to Washington Park - that is an ice rink, the former site of the Ferris Wheel.  This photo from the Ferris Wheel is taken looking back towards us.

BTW, I love how it is two New York museums - MOMA and Brooklyn Museum - that are tying together Chicago and Turkey.

comment.author: 73286033@N00
comment._content: Here's some postcard art showing the midway as it is now ifsing.org/db4/00368/ifsing.org/_uimages/UCpostcardtrimme... This second image shows the Master Plan for the University buildings and garden work. The green streak left to right is the Midway. There's a white oval dead center that's an Ice Skating rink, it is located where the Ferris Wheel was, they found the foundation when digging for the rink's construction. www.hydepark.org/hpkcc/genpics/MPmain1.JPG

comment.author: 29056926@N02
comment._content: Way back when, @Brooklyn_Museum posted researcher Ed's response to my listing of exhibits visible in this picture. I've found a map that matches Ed's description, here. On this page it's described as a "plan". The map I originally linked to is from a tourist brouchure on the Chicago History Museum's site. The main conflict is the location of the Irish Village. The tourist map shows two - an Irish Village alongside the Japanese Bazaar, and an "Irish Industries" in the location that the plan shows an Irish Village, next to the fair entrance. Here's a scene from Brooklyn's photostream. Another shot from across the Midway, showing grass in the foreground and perhaps a cafe on the right. This must be next to the fair entrance. The answer, though, is that there were two Irish Villages. One, between the Japanese Bazaar and Libby Glass Works, had a replica of Donegal Castle. The other, near the fair entrance, had a replica of Blarney Castle. A photo on page 99 of World's Fair through a Camera (1893) shows the glass works next to the Donegal Castle gate. Also a discussion of the two villages is on page xxv of Art & Architecture (1893). An example of the "change over time" of the fair... this photo shows the Irish Village on opening day, with Blarney Castle not yet built. The plan map also shows a Tower of Babel right before the fair entrance, which is missing in the tourist map and the actual photo.
